public class Main {     public static int frogCrossRiver(int distance, int stones, int currentPosition) {         // Base case: If the frog has reached the end of the river, return 0         if (currentPosition >= distance) {             return 0;         }          // Recursive case: Try both options (skip and not skip)         int skipStone = frogCrossRiver(distance, stones - 1, currentPosition + 2);         int notSkipStone = frogCrossRiver(distance, stones, currentPosition + 1);          // Return the minimum number of moves required         return 1 + Math.min(skipStone, notSkipStone);     }      public static void main(String[] args) {         int distance = 11; // Distance to cross the river         int stones = 10; // Number of stones         int currentPosition = 0; // Initial position of the frog          int minMoves = frogCrossRiver(distance, stones, currentPosition);         System.out.println("Minimum moves required: " + minMoves);     } }

I'm late but here goes:  yes, the return statement means 'stop', but stop once all code is run and your result is ready. because you're making a function call, your code will return the END of that function call. so it will go as far as the final return and then return the final result AFTER all function calls have been made.   so return func(n - 1) will work like this:  func(4) -> func(3) -> func(2) -> func(1) and lets just say you have a conditional that says if n <=1 return 1. It hits that conditional and returns the results back up the chain. Hope this helped

@supamdeepbains5172  Well return doesn't exactly mean "stop", it's like return the result to whoever asks.  and the caller keeps calling till the final one is returned then it starts to process the result.

@supamdeepbains5172  Each function call goes on a stack(memory), so in case of recursion when the function calls itself an entry is made on the stack with the current snapshot of the local variables, when return is called the entry from the stack is popped, and when all the entries are popped the complete function returns.

Feel free to point out if I'm mistaken.   // (frog) |--o--o--o--| function countFrogRoutesTroughRiver(riverLength) {   // COUNTS LAST STEPS POSSIBLE AS 1 (does not distinguish 1-2 step at last iteration)    // steps possible: 1-step and 2-step   if (riverLength <= 1) return 1;   let counter = 0;   counter += countFrogRoutesTroughRiver(riverLength - 1); // short step   counter += countFrogRoutesTroughRiver(riverLength - 2); // long step   return counter; }  console.log(countFrogRoutesTroughRiver(11)); // 144

Written in a promise because apparently, it has a higher performance on jspref  fibArray = (num, maxIndex) => {      return new Promise(function(resolve, reject) {         let fibArray = [1,1,2,3];         let i = 0;         while (i <= maxIndex) {                             if (fibArray[i] == num) {                     break;                 } else if (fibArray[i] != 1 && fibArray[i] != 2) {                     fibArray.push(fibArray[i] + fibArray[i-1])                 } else if ((fibArray[i] == num && i == maxIndex) || fibArray[i] == num && i == maxIndex) {                     reject(`Number could not be found up to ${maxIndex} index`);                 }             i++;         }          resolve(`${fibArray[i]} is at position ${i}`);     }) }

fibonacci series term in recursion: no_of_terms = int(input("Enter the number of terms you want to print of the Fibonacci series: "))  fib_dict = {1:1, 2:1}           # Creating a dictionary with initially just 2 values for term 1 and term 2 of the fibonacci series, that will be used to store the calculated results.  def rec_fib(term_num):     fib_num = 0     if term_num > 2:         if term_num in fib_dict.keys():             return fib_dict[term_num]         else:             fib_num = rec_fib(term_num-1) + rec_fib(term_num-2)             fib_dict[term_num] = fib_num             return fib_dict[term_num]     elif term_num in (1, 2):         return fib_dict[term_num]     else:         print("There is no fibonacci term below term number 1, please try again!")         return None   print(rec_fib(no_of_terms))

My solution to the frog problem coded in python: def Edfib(n):     if n >= 3:         return (Edfib(n-1) + Edfib(n-2))     elif n == 2:         return (2)     elif n == 1:         return (1)     elif n <= 0:         return ("no river for the frog to jump over so there are no")   n = int(input("Please enter the length in ft of the river your frog needs to jump across, remember your frog can only make leaps of 1ft or 2ft: ")) print("There is " + str(Edfib(n)) + " ways for your frog to get across")     Using this code it will ask you to enter the length of the river which you enter 11 for this purpose and it will tell you there are 144 ways for the frog to do so which is correct.             Explanation to my answer and why I coded it the way I did: First I wrote down 7 different cases, case 1 = river of 1 ft, case 2 = river of 2 ft, .......etc until case 7 = river of 7 ft. I then found the number of ways to cross the river given our constraints. I also set a rule for you extra picky people where the frog cannot over jump the river meaning if the river is 7 ft the frog can only jump a total distance of 7 ft he cant take a long leap for no apparent reason and end up at 8 ft. Although he technically crossed the river by taking that long leap and ending up at 8 ft it just causes too many extra cases to arise and from his explanation in the video the frog should not be taking extra leaps just a perfect amount to cross the river. After looking at the ways to cross the river for each case it turns out the pattern was just the Fibonacci sequence again :(  we did all that work to code the same exact thing we just coded a few seconds before. But at least it shows we could apply what the video taught us. I called my function Edfib which means Ed Fibonacci i'm sorry if that offends anyone just know I don't mean it in a way that is making fun of mentally disabled people I just use the word on a regularly basis to mean dumb. Anyways I made the assumption that if the length of the river was 0 (n = 0) there was no river of course and found one small tweak that makes it different from the original Fibonacci sequence. Instead of one base case there are 2 because unlike the original which states that at n = 2 the answer is 1 this is incorrect for the frog leap. At n = 2 there are actually two ways to jump across like stated in the video. This of course could have been bypassed if we let n = 0 return 1 then Edfib at 2 = Edfib at 1 + Edfib at 0 = 1 + 1 = 2 but that just makes no sense how can there be one way to jump across no river. So that sums up my explanation on how I coded the problem and found that if this frog wants to cross this 11 ft river there are 144 ways to do so. Recursive methods work by calling themselves while passing slightly different parameters. Eventually the parameters will change to hit the special case which works as a sort of exit condition. The call to fact(5) will return 5 * fact(4) which will in turn return 4 * fact(3)....all the way until you hit the special case of fact(0) which returns 1. Then they multiply backwards times the constants from the other calls as they generate an actual return value from the return statement.

I'm late but here goes:  yes, the return statement means 'stop', but stop once all code is run and your result is ready. because you're making a function call, your code will return the END of that function call. so it will go as far as the final return and then return the final result AFTER all function calls have been made.   so return func(n - 1) will work like this:  func(4) -> func(3) -> func(2) -> func(1) and lets just say you have a conditional that says if n <=1 return 1. It hits that conditional and returns the results back up the chain. Hope this helped
